channel.title: BBC News - Europe
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Polish law on property stolen by Nazis angers Israel
item.description: A new law will make it harder for people to recover property lost in World War Two.

item.title: Turkey floods: Death toll near Black Sea rises to at least 40
item.description: Flash floods in northern Turkey are the country's second natural disaster this month.

item.title: 'My night in notorious Nazi collaborator Quisling's cabin'
item.description: When Ben McPherson realised he could rent Vidkun Quisling's cabin, it struck him as weird. His Norwegian wife disagreed.

item.title: Sarah Rainsford on Russia: 'I've been told I can't come back - ever'
item.description: The BBC's Sarah Rainsford, devastated after being told she could not return to Russia, ever.

item.title: Channel migrant crossings reach record high as man dies
item.description: The UK deals with 592 people crossing the Channel on the day a migrant makes a fatal leap into the sea.

item.title: Climate change: Does Germany produce double the UK's carbon emissions?
item.description: MP John Redwood claims that, on carbon emissions, Germany "puts out twice as much as we do". Is he right?

item.title: Wagner: Gaddafi's son faces arrest over Russian mercenaries
item.description: A warrant is issued against Saif al-Islam Gaddafi after a BBC investigation into mercenaries in Libya.

item.title: No Messi, no Ramos - how is La Liga shaping up?
item.description: No Lionel Messi, no Sergio Ramos, no Zinedine Zidane - how are Spain's 'big three' looking - or could there be a new title winner?

item.title: Kiwi Chow: The film-maker who took Hong Kong's protests to Cannes
item.description: Kiwi Chow's documentary was a surprise at the film festival - and it has a controversial title.

item.title: Bardsey: Lure of the island with no electricity or wi-fi
item.description: There is no hot water or showers on the island, and it is thought that is why people are attracted.

item.title: Berlin embassy arrest: A case of old-school spying?
item.description: Why nothing in the case of the arrest of a man at the British Embassy in Berlin should surprise us.

item.title: Picasso masterpieces to go on sale in blockbuster auction
item.description: Proceeds could reach $100m in what is thought to be the most valuable auction of the artist's works.

item.title: The shopkeeper saving his island from wildfires
item.description: Spyros isn't a firefighter, but when his home was threatened with wildfires, he decided to take action.

item.title: Greece fires: Hundreds rescued by coastguard
item.description: The coastguard moved 650 people from Limni, in the north of the island of Evia.

item.title: Lukashenko: 'You can choke on your sanctions in the UK'
item.description: The UK and US are tightening sanctions on Belarus, hitting economic sectors.

item.title: 'They call me the Irish hulk of basketball'
item.description: Aidan Igiehon is part of a group of elite Irish athletes playing college basketball in America.

item.title: Will Turkey's bees return after the wildfires?
item.description: Residents of Marmaris, Turkey, are mourning their bees and honey, lost to fires.

item.title: Tankus the Henge: Touring in France post-Brexit 'a puzzle'
item.description: Band Tankus the Henge negotiates touring in France, their first trip there since Brexit rules were imposed.
